instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Green Light On Charger
threads.message:
Hi,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that hasn't had any water damage and shows a green light on the charger but does not power on. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> are all present and correct. Testing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> I noticed their voltages were pulsating.

I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> but it made no difference it is still doing the same thing. Are there any other components that can cause this issue?

Thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Green Light On Charger
threads.message: PPBUS stable? Without battery connected light should go green then orange.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Green Light On Charger
threads.message: Yes it stays stable at 12.4 volts and goes green then orange.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Green Light On Charger
threads.message: As <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is pulsing check what <SIGNAL>S5_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is doing. Also check all rails for shorts.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Green Light On Charger
threads.message: I figured out what was wrong. It had a short on <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> caused by <CAPACITOR>C2950</CAPACITOR>. I replaced it and it is working fine now. Thanks for your help.
